block.p: PALM SELLS 25% STAKE -- Palm, the struggling hand-held device company that makes the Treo, reached a deal to sell a quarter of the company to Elevation Partners, a private equity firm, for about $325 million. [Page C1.]

A FRENZY FOR IPHONE -- It has been almost six months since Steven P. Jobs introduced the iPhone, and hysteria for what some have called ''the God machine'' is beginning to reach levels usually reserved for video-game consoles at Christmas. [C1.]

WEATHER CHANNEL HEATS UP -- The weather may not be controversial, but the broader topic of climate change has generated no end of debate. As the Weather Channel's primary subject turns into a hot-button issue, it has had to grapple with how specifically it wants to address it. [C1.]

MAGAZINES GO IN-HOUSE FOR ADS -- Magazine companies traditionally have made money by selling ad space in their magazines or, more recently, on their Web sites. Now some of them have set up internal mini-agencies to design campaigns for their own pages. Advertising. [C1.]

DEAL IN CHIP DESIGN -- Cadence Design Systems, one of the largest makers of the software used to design computer chips, is in talks with at least two buyout firms about a possible sale of the company. [C2.]

THE MINT'S TWO CENTS -- The United States Mint has taken exception to a promotional stunt for the summer movie ''Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer'' -- 40,000 quarters altered to bear an image of the Silver Surfer. [C6.]

PAYING TO LOOK AT JOB LISTS -- A growing number of niche sites devoted to high-end jobs are finding that applicants are willing to pay for access. Marc Cenedella, above, chief executive of TheLadders.com, which lists jobs paying $100,000 or more, said the site was on pace to exceed $30 million in sales this year. E-Commerce Report: Bob Tedeschi. [C5.]

LEG UP FOR A START-UP -- Harvard plans to announce today the exclusive licensing for more than 50 current and pending Harvard patents to a little-known company, Nano-Terra Inc., that could transform it into one of nanotechnology's most closely watched start-ups. [C5.]

THE PERIL OF NOT TALKING TECH -- The latest example of the danger of revealing technological weakness is a British judge who, while presiding over an antiterrorism trial, was quoted as saying in open court: ''The trouble is, I don't understand the language. I don't really understand what a Web site is.'' Link by Link. [C4.]

BETTER NETFLIX RECOMMENDATIONS -- Netflix announced last year that it would award $1 million to the developer of a system that was at least 10 percent more accurate than its current system for recommending movies to customers. After more than 12,000 sets of guesses, the improvement level to Netflix's rating system is now at 7.42 percent. [C5.]

COVERING CONRAD BLACK -- The leading Canadian newsmagazine Maclean's has some connections with Conrad M. Black that complicate its role as an impartial chronicler of his trial on fraud charges. Mr. Black's wife is a Maclean's columnist, and the magazine's editor in chief is a close friend of Mr. Black's. [C6.]

BOB MARLEY ON FLASH DRIVE -- For the 30th anniversary of Bob Marley's ''Exodus,'' Island Records produced 4,000 flash drives that come loaded with the original 10 songs and additional tracks and videos. [C6.]

CAMPAIGN MUSIC FOR CLINTON -- When Senator Hillary Clinton asked YouTube viewers to vote on a theme song for her presidential campaign, she got the attention she wanted -- and a lot of jokes at her expense. [C6.]

LET ME TALK ABOUT MY BOOK -- In an effort to counter shrinking shelf lives of books, disappearing book review sections and a fading audience attention span, several major publishing houses have set up speakers bureaus to sell books after the initial publicity campaign and to help authors earn extra money. [C6.]

$1.6 BILLION DEAL FOR DIGENE -- Qiagen, a Dutch maker of tools for gene research, has agreed to buy the Digene Corporation for $1.6 billion in shares and cash to gain tests for a virus that causes cervical cancer and sexually transmitted diseases. [C2.]
CELLPHONE PROVIDER STRUGGLES -- Amp'd Mobile, a niche cellphone provider aimed at young sophisticated users, has filed for bankruptcy protection. [C4.]
